children.subject: This happens to a lot of people! My first year I got a B in 16A, and I felt a bit upset, but the next semester I managed to get an A in 61B. I then felt a lot more confident and realized I was better at certain parts of EECS than others, and it's kind of still the case--my EE and math-y classes put me at lower grades than software and programming-heavy courses (so I tend to try to take the latter in my UDs).  Others I've talked to struggle because the class doesnt have enough math, some because there's not enough practical knowledge taught, some because they don't like projects, etc. The EECS major spans a lot of different skillsets so don't be upset if you aren't amazing at the all the different kinds of classes (you may also be good at something that is outside your major, as is my case since I am double majoring). If you got As in some technical courses, that's already pretty amazing, just something to think about.

lol i got a c+ in ee16a and that same semester i got an A- in 61A. I've also gotten subpar grades in a lot of humanities classes. I wouldn't sweat it, it's pretty normal, and of course students are going to have to make compromises and deprioritize certain classes that aren't as vital to their degree/career goals.

history.content:
In my experience, this will be generally true because of the curves. It's also generally easier to get good grades in CS division upper divs than EE/EECS division upper divs because the curves are very generous and large class sizes means there will be a lot more people who have no idea what they're doing, even relatively.

For example, say someone gets a B in CS 70 by the skin of their teeth and manages to declare. There are two logical follow-up classes to 70: CS 170 and EECS 126. They will feel strongly required to take 170, so they'll take it despite not doing very well. However, this hypothetical person is probably not taking EE 126, since they don't even like math in the first place. Thus, the 200 people in EECS 126 will be a lot more competitive than the 800 in CS 170.

Or, to go with a systems example, say someone gets a B in 61C by the skin of their teeth. The two logical followups to 61C are probably CS 162 and EECS 151. Said person will probably take CS 162 out of a feeling of obligation, but probably won't ever seriously consider EECS 151 because it's considered difficult and esoteric. EECS 151 is a 50 person class compared to CS 162's 500.

So yes, your grades in technical courses will vary wildly based off what they are. Classes that lots of people take like 170, you'll tend to get better grades. Esoteric 50 person classes in EECS will make you go through the wringer

----------

I think class size does matter, but it really depends on your strength. That's why people have different interests. I took 61B and 70 concurrently, got near A+ in 70 but B in 61B, got high A in 189 but B+ in 188. I am good at algebra but poor at geometry, got A+ in 54 but C in 53 (I used late pnp for it because I can't understand the class at all). It's not the case that people who took 61B were stronger than those who took 70, who took 188 were stronger than those who took 189, or those who took 53 were stronger than those who took 54. It really depends on your strength.

In my experience, this will be generally true because of the curves. It's also generally easier to get good grades in CS division upper divs than EE/EECS division upper divs because the curves are very generous and large class sizes means there will be a lot more people who have no idea what they're doing, even relatively.

Thus, the 200 people in EECS 126 will be a lot more competitive than the 800 in CS 170.

Or, to go with a systems example, say someone gets a B in 61C by the skin of their teeth. The two logical followups to 61C are probably CS 162 and EECS 151. Said person will probably take CS 162 out of a feeling of obligation, but probably won't ever seriously consider EECS 151 because it's considered difficult and esoteric. EECS 151 is a 50 person class compared to CS 162's 500.

So yes, your grades in technical courses will vary wildly based off what they are. Classes that lots of people take like 170, you'll tend to get better grades. Esoteric 50 person classes in EECS will make you go through the wringer

Hi! I want to ask for some personal experiences and advices about grade discrepancy across multiple technical courses. For instance, one may have achieved multiple As on many technical courses, but B+ level grade on few class. Is this uncommon?  Do you have similar experience? How do you recover/cheer up your confidence from this situation? 

Thank you so much!
history.subject: Have anyone encountered grade discrepancy across multiple technical courses?

history.content:
